title: Wednesday, 21st November 2018
bodyHTML:
Blank canvas hi
11:08 am
BE11:09am

Hello!

Grouchmonkey Hi. Eurgh.
BE11:09am

Good morning, hi, welcome, hey there.

SupposeToBeWorking... Morning all
BE11:10am

This is Markets Live and there's too much going on.

VV75 morning
Soundbuy Morning
RAVER Good morning all
11:10 am
BE11:10am

Where to start? I guess there's here.

z1p good morning, any press release from EUCO on the against italy?
BE11:11am

Manxish Morning everyone
BE11:11am

Bitcoin on Google trends.

VV75 I would be interested in some comments on Indivior
Soundbuy SSP Group if you have time later........
nightingale20201 Morning all
11:12 am
BE11:12am

And remarkably similar to the Bitcoin price chart. It's been noted many many many times that mentions in the press correlate pretty well to bitcoin price action.

BE11:13am

Which is probably the best argument you have for buying into the current puke-out.

nightingale20201 you can superimpose the Bitcoin chart with the NVDA chart
wayneJ Bloomberg article today - opening para: China’s plan to judge each of its 1.3 billion people based on their social behavior is moving a stepcloser to reality, with Beijing set to adopt a lifelong pointsprogram by 2021 that assigns personalized ratings for eachresident.
Billy morning all
Grouchmonkey Yes, Indivior, Johnson Matthey, Breedon all of interest.
undefined
11:13 am
BE11:14am

But who cares about crypto when there's heroin?!

BE11:14am

(Some synergies between those two markets, obv.)

wayneJ I am wondering if the same will come to the UK under glorious Brexit. Does the FT log this chat and is it impacting my future social behaviour ranking?
Indivior PLC (INDV:LSE): Last: 97.51, down 12.44 (-11.32%), High: 110.25, Low: 94.18, Volume: 4.82m
Excel Developer @nightingale20201: because you need the microchips to do the bitcoin mining no doubt.
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Okay, here's the upshot. They're knackered.

Grouchmonkey I note Indivior said nothing about Sublocade in its reaction to the Soboxone court decision.
BE11:15am

News broke yesterday afternoon that the US appeals court had reversed the injunction stopping Dr Reddy's from selling generic Suboxone.

wayneJ Apparently you can be blocked from booking flights in China if you have poor social credit. Will the ERG implement the same in the UK? All remoaners to be allocated to 'poor social credit' and FTAV ML users doubly so?
chopper bear babcock if poss please BE
BE11:16am

To remind, Dr Reddy's already has FDA clearance and has a load of supplies waiting to roll. The injunction was on a patent dispute.

VV75 last time they immediately flooded the marketplace
11:17 am
BE11:17am

So, we have a very high likelihood that the Suboxone market is about to be flooded and prices will drop, what, 90%?

BE11:17am

Which is extremely bad for Indivior because its follow-on skag treatment, Sublocade, just hasn't been selling.

Grouchmonkey @chopper co badly needs another "it's not true, we are NOT nincompoops" statement
Ethelred Who cares about heroin when you're long babcock...?
BE11:19am

Various reasons for that. Indivior's talked about difficulties with payment bodies and insurers and pharmacies and stuff. We've speculated here in the past that opium addiction isn't a condition that automatically defaults to the best available treatment rather than the cheapest one.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

The court case gave Indivior time to get Sublocade established while still generating income from Suboxone. Now .... well, not.

BE11:20am

So what happens next? Well, you look at debt.

BE11:20am

Here's Jefferies.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

We believe INDV will have to significantly cut price on its branded film, launch an authorised generic, cut its launch activities for Perseris,make significant adjustments to its cost base, and delay early stage R&D activities. We assumeINDV will have to either partner or pushback Perseris as it will not have the internal resources to market whilst also protecting its main asset, Sublocade. Given the fixed cost nature of the cost base, our new model assumes $200M cost savings in 2019 vs. the previously announced $100m, which we estimate is required to prevent breaching its covenants. Excluding these savings, our 2019 EPS revisions would be -134%.

BE11:21am

We now assume $490m peak global sales for our Sublocade base case vs $940m previously as believe limited resources leave INDV more challenged to develop the drug. Furthermore, we halve the value we ascribe to Perseris to reflect either a delay in full commercialisation or a partnering of the product. We assume an extra $100m cost savings in 2019 which equates to 70p of our 120p PT.

BE11:22am

And RBC.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

For us, the investment case rested on new asset
Sublocade and we believed a window existed for Indivior to convert patients from Film to the new product should it be able to keep the Film generics off the market. This window now appears to be closing and think we should be looking to more prudent scenarios. Whilst our forecasts suggest the company should emerge, in time, to a growth asset this is based upon the Sublocade improving, which we would suggest some caution with as the forecast risk remains high. Our updated SoTP scenario, which takes just the RoW franchise plus the residual Suboxone Film business comes to 130p and potentially 290p with Sublocade a success on our lowered estimates (suggesting it is an option at current levels, but not one we see many taking today).

BE11:23am

And Citi.

BE11:24am

We previously published ... a base case of 240p which assumed generics in 2019 and peak Sublocade sales of $600m (vs company guidance of greater than $1bn), with downside of 17p for early generics and a further 42p for Perseris, which, although commercially available will now not have a full commercial launch in Feb-19. We note that, as of 3Q18 results, net cash per share was 76p, with the balance of value now made up by the ROW business, expectations for Sublocade and Perseris, offset by any legal liabilities.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

"offset by any legal liabilities" is a phrase that requires some consideration, given Indivor's history.

undefined
BornCynic Morning - if anyone is interested you can now sign up for Mr Authers new column.
BE11:25am

(@Borncynic: mate, ffs.)

11:25 am
BE11:26am

I'll never in my life understand why Babcock gets so much attention.

Babcock International Group PLC (BAB:LSE): Last: 551.60, down 42.6 (-7.17%), High: 563.20, Low: 521.00, Volume: 2.73m
BE11:26am

Results are in line, outlook's a curate's egg.

hedgehog Ssp please
11:26 am
BE11:26am

Big Magnox step down in the FY2020 is the major new negative.

Blank canvas buying babcock seemed like such a good idea at the time
BE11:28am

£250m revenue step-down vs £100m previously, which has a mechanical effect on the consensus.

BE11:28am

£250m revenue equals around £18m of operating profit apparently.

BornCynic BE - I was careful not to mention where it was BE. Apologies.
PostmanPat Sage please
Ethelred Babcock is good soap opera ,,, shorters , politicians , colourful characters crazy price movements, mysterious research reports
11:29 am
BE11:29am

You also get £120.4m of exceptional charges, mostly restructuring plus oil and gas write-downs.

BE11:29am

Here's Caz to summarise the outlook.

Pharma with the added bonus of sounding like a plumbers' merchant
BE11:30am

Group organic revenue, excluding the impact of business exits, increased by 0.5% in H1 y/y. Underlying operating profit rose 2.4% y/y, with particularly strong growth in Land, offset by a weaker Marine performance. The group’s pipeline and orderbook are stable at £32bn, with forward revenue visibility at similar levels to last year. Babcock’s relationship with the MOD remains positive, with £650m of MOD work added to the group’s order book in H1. No change to the group’s delevering targets, with cash flow much improved y/y.

AC21 Kingfisher's doing badly today
11:30 am
BE11:30am

And the writedowns.

BE11:30am

H1 results include £120.4m of pre-tax exceptionals. Oil
& Gas assets have been written down by a total £80.3m. Restructuring charges of £39.6m have been taken across Appledore, Rail, Rosyth and Magnox. Proceeds from the sale of media services have offset the cost of exiting other non-core areas of the group. Total cash costs of these items were £5m in H1, and are expected to be £15m for FY19e, with modest inflows beyond this from Oil & Gas asset sales.

BE11:32am

I guess, beyond the extremely muddy detail, what we get is another forecast downgrade -- in spite of the 2018 outlook reiteration. Babcock never fails to disappoint somehow.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

RBC incoming.

urgeview Any chance of some SSP Group coverage ? TIA.
BE11:32am

Today’s results do little to restore confidence in either the management of this business or it’s near-term outlook, we believe, albeit on a CY20E PE of 8x
(EV/EBITA of 7.5x) and dividend yield of 5%, it could be argued that much of the perceived risk in the business is being discounted. However, the run up to the
interims has been poorly handled, in our view, and has served as a good reminder of why the shares have underperformed so significantly. With consensus
numbers having to come down again and further question marks arising we retain our view that there needs to be management change before this becomes
interesting from an equity standpoint.

BE11:33am

And Stifel.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

Half year results are pretty much as anticipated with flat sales on an underlying basis (ex disposals & FX) and operating margins slightly up to 10.9% with profits +2%. Cash generation looks good with 82% cash conversion post capex, in line with medium-term targets. However there is a £120m exceptional charge (£10m cash cost) related to the reshaping of the group's oil & gas business, the exits & disposals programme and capacity rightsizing. The outlook statement for FY19 is unchanged (low single digit organic growth with improved margins) but FY20 numbers are likely to come down by c. 3% with the company warning that it has changed its assumptions over the shape of the Magnox step-down. The disposals programme is also expected to have a small impact on FY20 numbers. Bottom line: management is taking welcome steps to strengthen the business but we doubt this will be enough to fully restore investor confidence in the equity story.

Ebitdaddy morning
BE11:34am

Going to be a big day for the word "embattled", I suspect.

undefined
11:34 am
BE11:34am

SSP? Rightyho.

BE11:35am

Kate Swann's off.

Excel Developer sandwich monopolies!
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian I wish you guys at the FT would stop giving Boatman Capital column inches. It is just adding weight to a dubious outfit IMO.
BE11:35am

Or "business genius" Kate Swann, as Clive Black refers to her this morning.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

(@Fletch: barely mentioned them here, FWIW.)

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Matthew Vincent guilty again this morning!
BE11:36am

SSP is one of the most consistent and highest quality operators in the listed consumer arena in our view. The Group was floated at quite full ratios expecting good and consistent financial delivery. Whilst such an out turn was wished for, boy has Kate Swann and her team consistently and diligently delivered against a plan that is quite focused, nay dull at times, in its detail but exciting in the amalgam. Progress from SSP is broad based. Management has seized upon the opportunity that is posed by I international air travel across the globe whilst not ignoring the more stable cash flows that can emerge from the more mundane markets in European rail; if one tries to regularly travel in the creaking UK network of Northern England then the SSP's facilities are a source of deep joy.., as we do as analysts based two hundred miles from Central London!

SSP is a superb operator and defined by an attention to detail, which makes Kate Swann one of the greatest, but as yet still only partially recognised, business genius' of the present commercial era, and we do not make that claim lightly. Four upgrades in FY2018.., on far from tame comparatives, plus material margin accretion over the last four to five years, taking contract mobilisation forces into account, reveal the balanced, considered and broad base of the Group. It is with disappointment then to hear that she is stepping down as CEO next May. Her position is to be taken by the Simon Smith, the current head of UK, which has seen significant profit growth, despite tough trading conditions across rail. Although we expect a negative reaction from the market today (given the rating), we see many similarities with WH Smith, where the culture embedded should see the group continue to deliver further efficiencies against a backdrop of favourable structural growth opportunities in global travel.

BE11:37am

Hmmm .........................

11:37 am
BE11:37am

........ I mean, it's a kind of genius to move between two companies that both operate in an industry with cartel-like qualities.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian "barely mentioned them here" Thanks BE. I know. Just an observation. :)
BE11:38am

Whilst operational delivery is there to experience as a traveller, day in, day out, SSP, balances strong profit delivery with robust solvency ratios, so a FY2018 out-turn of 1.1x net debt (ND)/EBITDA ratio. Accordingly, based upon such cash flow and balance sheet ratios, the Group has declared a FY2018 DPS of 43p (SC forecast; 32p), which we deem to be worth having, noting the special element of the distribution. We have stated before that simply maintaining the current ND/EBITDA ratio (c1.1x, with guidance of 1.5-2.0x) may lead the Group, material M&A aside, to delivering c25% of its present market capitalisation over the next five years and all of the present equity value over the next decade in an income stream..., no mean feat whatsoever.

Hence, SSP is a great cash compounder investment story. We could have used the term has been or was.., but the reality is that raises Group is a great cash compounder. We continue to see ongoing growth and additional shareholder value coming from this class act; our most recent income stream analysis suggested a share price of c830p..., albeit after the FY2018 results we shall revisit such analysis.

Little in investment terms is perfect but SSP has been as perfect at it becomes as a listed entity, the IPO of which Shore Capital remains proud to have participated in. Based upon the FY2018 out-turn we are likely to upgrade our pre-share consolidation 2019F EPS by c2-3% to 27p to reflect the better than expected outcome (and continuation of 2-3% LFL revenue growth, 3% net new contracts and 20bps margin), although we shall finesse matters after the analyst meeting and thereafter plus our own engagement with management. Accordingly, after these events we reconfirm our long-standing BUY recommendation although we would expect some weakness today.

Grouchmonkey Yes, I read the Boatman "research" and it is pretty amateurish
Grouchmonkey Which is not to say the criticisms aren't valid, mind
BE11:39am

Citi also buying on weakness.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Ms. Swann is an exceptional operator and any business would miss her expertise and detailed, extensive knowledge. We think a material negative share price reaction could represent a buying opportunity. We note that when Ms. Swann left WH Smith on Novmeber 20, 2012, the share price fell on the day only to then increase from c. £5 per share to £19.26 now (the FTSE 250 was up 57.34% over the same time frame).

BE11:40am

.............. yeah, odd that WH Smith didn't collapse post Ms Swann's departure.

BE11:41am

You'd have thought that might focus the mind on whether there are links -- operational synergies, you might say -- between the companies that transcend C-suite structures.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Boatman: No mention at Companies House, unknown sponsors, domicile in Panama, zero transparency ????
11:41 am
BE11:42am

Try to buy a sandwich in a train station and see if you can get the gist of what I mean.

BE11:42am

Goldman are sellers here.

BE11:43am

Basically just on valuation.

11:42 am
BE11:43am

Our 12-month price target is 615p and our rating is Sell. Our price target is based on a target P/E multiple of 22.0x, applied to our calendarised 2019 estimate. We also include the potential value of excess cash spend on share buybacks in our valuation.

BE11:44am

To that I'd wonder aloud how a company so reliant on transport footfall and exposed to hospitality industry costs doesn't get the same kind of cyclical valuation as a transport operator or a hospitality industry company.

BE11:45am

It's a real mystery, that. Proper conundrum.

11:45 am
undefined
BE11:46am

Johnson Matthey -- mentioned somewhere back there -- is just a bounce really.

BornCynic The cult of the CEO / management - reminds me of this quote:Paul Krugman wryly noted, "Whom the Gods would destroy, they first put on the cover of Business Week."
Johnson Matthey PLC (JMAT:LSE): Last: 3,036, up 259 (+9.33%), High: 3,067, Low: 2,937, Volume: 497.61k
11:46 am
BE11:46am

Fell like 25% or so since the September peak on all the car company warnings.

BE11:46am

Turns out they're doing okay. Sales guidance raised.

BT I'd imagine SSP is very much a source of extreme joy if you're travelling on expenses, as I'd imagine they "do as analysts based two hundred miles from Central London!"
BE11:47am

Operating performance at constant FX towards the upper end of its mid-to-high single digit growth for 2019.

Pharma On a vaguely related tangent: How long before the South African government decides to use its new powers to confiscate property without compensation to "redistribute" mining rights?
Tony Scott a lot of speculation in BAB Boatman note. 'We understand CEO kicked out of meeting'
11:49 am
BE11:49am

Nothing particularly new in there with regards battery investment, which is the bull to the death-of-catalysts bear.

BE11:49am

Here's Citi.

BE11:49am

These are a robust set of results showing that the share gains in LDV diesel are able to drive material EPS growth, together with HDD. We think these results imply modest (0-5%) consensus upgrades. We expect the business to recover most of the one-time item hampering working capital and therefore FCF in the half. In clarification, JMAT has detailed further its contingent liabilities which relate to only 2 customers and notes the failures have not been demonstrated to be due to the coated substrate supplied by JMAT. JMAT believes it has defensible warranty positions in the matter, highlighting that any impact should be limited. With tighter emissions legislation in both HDD & LDV providing a positive backdrop for growth both near-term and medium-term in addition to their potential in cathode materials, we think the current share price continues to under-estimate the growth potential of the business– BUY.

GGekko TalkTalk coming back?
11:50 am
undefined
RAVER Johnson Matthey bounce back to level last trading at two days ago
PostmanPat Anything on Sage?
BE11:52am

What else? Flashes crossing Bloomberg about Foxconn cutting its budget by 20bn yuan next year.

BE11:53am

Because of "a very difficult and competitive year,” Borg says, citing an internal memo.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

So .... more iPhone gloom. Though 20bn yuan is, what, $3bn-ish?

VV75 yep 2,9bn
wayneJ Er - doesn't Foxconn employ around 900,000 people
BE11:55am

So that's the annual salaries of 273,972 Foxconn workers, I guess.

BE11:55am

($3bn/365 in case you're wondering. Please don't sue us.)

11:55 am
undefined
Blackbag99 I only own apple shorts, so any doom is most welcome
BE11:56am

Sage requested. So they've discovered this thing called the cloud.

wayneJ @BE - bit insensitive for those 273,972 people - your social credit rating might get marked down, comrade....
Sage Group PLC (SGE:LSE): Last: 517.00, down 19.2 (-3.58%), High: 520.40, Low: 491.30, Volume: 2.49m
11:56 am
BE11:57am

And management are right on it with an apparently one-off (heheheheheh) £60m investment.

RAVER Not sure Foxxcon workers earn $10k / year
wayneJ And on your mafs, at a reasonable salary, say $20k that would a lot less worker-comrades
alewis2005 god if sage actually ever manage to move their customer base onto the cloud I'll be very happy
BE11:57am

Which means margin guidance gets bumped down for next year from 27ish percent to 24ish.

wayneJ Note that the real issue is whether Apple is moving production out of China - remember Foxconn meant to be opening a large plant in the US.
BE11:58am

The result is double-digit EPS downgrades for 2019, though it looks like these were mostly anticipated.

wayneJ And it was peculiar the way the US tariffs had an exemption for handsets - always wondered why the White House did that?
11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Whether you believe the £60m investment is a sufficient one-off to cure Sage's antediluvian approach to software is another question. (A question to which the answer is: "it's not".)

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Thanks BE on Babcock & JMAT. Both handy for me. FT back into my good books!
BE12:00pm

Goldman incoming.

wayneJ In fact the Borg says Foxconn will let 10% of 'non-technical' staff go.
BE12:00pm

While the FY18 results were broadly in line, we believe the FY19 guidance (c.5%-7% organic revenue growth based on our calculations and 23%-25% operating margin, given one time investment into transition to SaaS) could result in a significant consensus estimates reset for FY19 margins. The shares are down c.30% YTD, which we believe is due to the market already anticipating street expectations would come down to reflect the ongoing business model transition. While the shares have opened lower today, we note that Sage is trading towards its trough EV/EBITDA and EV/Recurring multiple (c.10x CY19E EV/EBITDA and 3.8x CY19E EV/Recurring on our estimates, respectively), and we see valuation as undemanding at these levels.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

And Morgan Stanley.

wayneJ And says Foxconn reviewing managers with 'an annual compensation of more than $150,000' -
BE12:01pm

Investment a clear positive mid-term but earnings cut will weigh short-term: We have highlighted in previous research (here) that we felt Sage needed to invest in order to improve its product offering - especially into SaaS. The £60m investment which takes operating margins down 2-4pp in FY19 is clearly a strong shift in this direction with Sage flagging investment in Sage Business Cloud overall, internationalising Intacct and better SaaS systems. We believe this is a clear positive for the mid-long term of the group - although investors will also want to be reassured that the investment can drive a faster pace of innovation. We would not expect margins to bounce back to prior levels in FY20 - but continuing cost savings could mean the pace of margin expansion increases from FY20 onwards. On the other hand, while we think investors were expecting some earnings reset, we think a low teens earnings cut for street will still send the shares down today. However, we see strong valuation support for the shares at 500p (below 4x CY19 EV/recurring revenues) and so would not expect the shares to fall as much as the street earnings downgrade. The fact the dividend will be maintained "in real terms" is also a small positive. We would look to turn more positive on either valuation or confidence the pace of delivery of Sage's innovation has changed.

BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR
SupposeToBeWorking... Thanks
wayneJ Others may be able to correct me but does the Bloomberg article say the cuts of 3billion yuan are at Foxconn Industrial Internet Co. - which is a listed sub
BE12:02pm

And Barclays.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Sage had said more than we anticipated with its FY18 results, making this perhaps more of an event than expected. Firstly, it delivered 6.6% organic growth for the FY18 and 27.2% margin, making it a bit of a stretch to argue that the business is in line with the ~7% guidance and ~27.5% margin, although the market was largely anticipating this. This equates to Q4 growth of 6.9% growth, only a very slight tick up on the 6.8% from Q3, despite the anticipated licence closures. It has though, as it has in the past, identified a lower margin, lower growth business within the mix to dispose of and argues that growth would have been 6.8% without this and margin 27.8%.

More important is the guidance, which reads more like we would have expected were an external SaaS-focused CEO to have been appointed. The company is guiding to 280-480bp of margin decrease next year, in order to accelerate the transition to the cloud. This will bring the margin (excluding the asset held for sale) from 27.8% this year to 23-25%. However, Sage is also guiding that organic growth may decrease in the near-term as it goes through this transition; within the mix it expects 8-9% recurring revenue growth, but for processing and SSRS to be flat to mid single digit decline.

Overall, as we have previously argued, Sage needs to transition to the cloud and we therefore see this as strategically to Sage’s benefit over the longer-term. However, as we have seen with others before it, cloud transitions are not quick and do require significant investment. With decelerating organic growth and lower margin, it will take time we expect for the market to begin to look through this.

undefined
Blank canvas thanks for your insights today - left and right hand sides of the screen
BE12:04pm

Have we missed anything? I'm sure we have. Oh, Kingfisher. Of course.

Ethelred Cheer up Babcockers - now up 7% from low this morning probably a few shorts checking out
12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

One Kingfisher is now in its 314th year and they're still struggling to narrow B&Q down to three rawlplug suppliers.

Kingfisher PLC (KGF:LSE): Last: 241.00, down 5.3 (-2.15%), High: 243.20, Low: 232.00, Volume: 5.61m
BE12:06pm

Trading's still weak. Sellside are still arguing about how management should just break the damn thing up, so they can recommend Screwfix without having to carry the other stuff around as baggage.

12:06 pm
BE12:07pm

Still no sign of that actually happening though, and Screwfix is slightly disappointing this time around, just to dent the theory further.

BE12:07pm

Who've we not quoted yet? Davy? Let's quote Davy.

BE12:07pm

The benefits from the implementation of the ONE Kingfisher strategy continue to be offset by a challenging Castorama business in France, while the B&Q business also remains weak. With no signs of improvement in the underlying trading conditions of either business, it remains difficult to be constructive on the name. The company can continue to buy back shares, but this will not be enough to merit a re-rating of the valuation.

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

Oh, and exiting Russia (they were in Russia!?) Spain and Portugal.

BE12:09pm

in order "to focus on markets where we have, or can reach, a market leading position".

BE12:09pm

Morgan Stanley:

12:09 pm
BE12:09pm

Management had flagged at the Interims that the losses being incurred in some of its smaller markets were unacceptable, so this is not a huge surprise. There is no guidance here, though, on whether the exits from these markets will raise or consume cash (we understand that around half the stores in Russia, and some of those in Spain too, are owned on a freehold basis)

Blackbag99 Sages problems are that they have no real ERP solutions. The software become defunct at small medium size enterprises. Medium medium size just exit, when they the bucks to buy software development.
BE12:10pm

-Having spoken to the company this morning, we think it likely that consensus forecasts will fall by a further 3-4% today, as a result of the ongoing weakness at Castorama. Kingfisher now reports three different definitions of profitability, which complicates the picture for third party consensus-gatherers, such as Bloomberg. However according to the Company's website, consensus is currently looking for Adjusted Pre Tax Profits (ie post c£135m of Transformation costs, but pre exceptional items) of £606m in FY 2018/19 (giving an EPS of 20.7p). We would anticipate that coming down to around £580m
- Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, Kingfisher is trading on 8.7x Cal 2019 earnings, 4.8x EBITDA with a 4.9% dividend yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 11.2x, 7.2x and 4.1% respectively

undefined
12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

And that'll do for Wednesday.

BE12:11pm

If you want some luxury goods guff there's a bit over here: https://www.ft.com...-89c8-d36339d835c0

Waterloo thanks
VV75 ta
RAVER Thanks BE
PostmanPat Thank you
BE12:11pm

Ta for the comments. Back tomorrow, and tomorrow, and all the tomorrows. Afternoon all.
